# Question

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here is a Julia function named `wrap_string` that iterates over words in an input string, wrapping the text so that no line exceeds a specified maximum width. The default width is set to 10 characters.

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    current_line = ""
    result = ""

    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) + 1 > text_width
            # If adding the new word exceeds the limit, finish the current line
            result = result * current_line * "\n"
            current_line = word  # Start a new line with the current word
        else
            # If not, add the word to the current line
            if isempty(current_line)
                current_line = word
            else
                current_line *= " " * word
            end
        end
    end

    # Add the final line to the result
    if !isempty(current_line)
        result = result * current_line
    end

    return result
end
```

Here is an example demonstrating how you could use the `wrap_string` function:

```julia
text = "Julia is a high-level, high-performance, dynamic programming language."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text)
println(wrapped_text)
```

This will display output with lines wrapped such that each contains no more than 10 characters, respecting word boundaries. You can modify `text_width` to change the maximum line length according to your specific needs.
